content: The "Neutral Cost Recovery Act for Small Business" may be cited as the short title. It includes increased expensing for small businesses. The "Neutral Cost Recovery Act for Small Business" includes increased expensing for small businesses, with a dollar limitation of $75,000 for the aggregate cost in any taxable year. The phaseout threshold is also increased. Section 179(b) of the Code is amended to increase the limitation from $200,000 to $325,000. Section 179(d)(1) now includes computer software as section 179 property. The text discusses the criteria for property to qualify for section 179, including being described in section 197(e)(3)(A)(i), section 1245 property, and acquired for use in a trade or business. It also excludes certain types of property and includes an inflation adjustment for the dollar limitation. The amendment to section 179 of the tax code includes inflation adjustments for dollar amounts in taxable years after 2003. Paragraph (2) of section 179(c) is amended to allow revocation of election under certain conditions. The amendments made by this section will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2002. SEC. 3. NEUTRAL COST RECOVERY DEPRECIATION ADJUSTMENT FOR CERTAIN PROPERTY PLACED IN SERVICE AFTER DECEMBER 31, 2003. Section 168 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow for a deduction adjustment to equivalent expensing for certain property placed in service after December 31, 2003. The amendment to Section 168 of the Internal Revenue Code allows for a deduction adjustment to equivalent expensing for certain property placed in service after December 31, 2003. This adjustment involves using a different percentage in the declining balance method and multiplying the determined amount for the taxable year by the applicable neutral cost recovery ratio based on the gross domestic product deflator. The deduction adjustment for property placed in service involves multiplying the determined amount by the gross domestic product deflator and a factor of 1.035 to the nth power. The applicable neutral cost recovery ratio is calculated by raising 1.035 to the power of the number of full years the property has been in service, and it should never be less than 1. The subsection provides rules for property deductions, including an election option, exceptions for certain transactions, and ensuring additional deductions do not affect basis or recapture. The additional deduction determined under this section shall not affect the adjusted basis of property or pass-thru entities holding the property, and it is not considered a depreciation deduction for sections 1245 and 1250. The term 'pass-thru entity' includes regulated investment companies, real estate investment trusts, S corporations, partnerships, estates, trusts, and common trust funds. This subparagraph does not apply to property with an election in effect not to have section 168(k) apply. Clause (i) does not apply to the additional deduction allowed by section 168(k). The amendment under section 168(k) relates to the coordination with the depreciation limitation on certain automobiles. It states that the unrecovered basis of any passenger automobile includes the additional amount determined under section 168(k) to the extent not allowed as a deduction.
